name: sys::thread_local::native::lazy::Storage::<T, D>::get_or_init_slow

core::ptr::null.doc:
Creates a null raw pointer.

 This function is equivalent to zero-initializing the pointer:
 `MaybeUninit::<*const T>::zeroed().assume_init()`.
 The resulting pointer has the address 0.

 # Examples

 ```
 use std::ptr;

 let p: *const i32 = ptr::null();
 assert!(p.is_null());
 assert_eq!(p as usize, 0); // this pointer has the address 0
 ```

core::ptr::mut_ptr::<impl *mut T>::cast.doc: Casts to a pointer of another type.

core::mem::MaybeUninit::<T>::new.doc:
Creates a new `MaybeUninit<T>` initialized with the given value.
 It is safe to call [`assume_init`] on the return value of this function.

 Note that dropping a `MaybeUninit<T>` will never call `T`'s drop code.
 It is your responsibility to make sure `T` gets dropped if it got initialized.

 # Example

 ```
 use std::mem::MaybeUninit;

 let v: MaybeUninit<Vec<u8>> = MaybeUninit::new(vec![42]);
 # // Prevent leaks for Miri
 # unsafe { let _ = MaybeUninit::assume_init(v); }
 ```

 [`assume_init`]: MaybeUninit::assume_init

core::ptr::mut_ptr::<impl *mut T>::repla.doc:
Replaces the value at `self` with `src`, returning the old
 value, without dropping either.

 See [`ptr::replace`] for safety concerns and examples.

 [`ptr::replace`]: crate::ptr::replace()

core::panicking::panic.doc: The underlying implementation of core's `panic!` macro when no formatting is used.

core::mem::MaybeUninit::<T>::assume_init.doc:
Drops the contained value in place.

 If you have ownership of the `MaybeUninit`, you can also use
 [`assume_init`] as an alternative.

 # Safety

 It is up to the caller to guarantee that the `MaybeUninit<T>` really is
 in an initialized state. Calling this when the content is not yet fully
 initialized causes undefined behavior.

 On top of that, all additional invariants of the type `T` must be
 satisfied, as the `Drop` implementation of `T` (or its members) may
 rely on this. For example, setting a `Vec<T>` to an invalid but
 non-null address makes it initialized (under the current implementation;
 this does not constitute a stable guarantee), because the only
 requirement the compiler knows about it is that the data pointer must be
 non-null. Dropping such a `Vec<T>` however will cause undefined
 behavior.

 [`assume_init`]: MaybeUninit::assume_init

doc:
# Safety
 The `self` reference must remain valid until the TLS destructor is run.
